values.description: Commit 4fcacc3 introduced the member "name" in Base.hh. A method in Model.cc is using a variable with the same name, so compiler is [complaining](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/drcsim_2.6/job/drcsim-drcsim_2.6-gazebo-gazebo_1.8-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/8/warnings13Result/new/?) about shadowing.
values.title: Fix collision of variable name and attribute in Model.cc

summary.raw: Commit 4fcacc3 introduced the member "name" in Base.hh. A method in Model.cc is using a variable with the same name, so compiler is [complaining](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/drcsim_2.6/job/drcsim-drcsim_2.6-gazebo-gazebo_1.8-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/8/warnings13Result/new/?) about shadowing.
summary.html: Commit 4fcacc3 introduced the member "name" in Base.hh. A method in Model.cc is using a variable with the same name, so compiler is complaining about shadowing.

values.description:
per [drcsim issue 308](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/308/inertia-calculation-for-fixed-joints)

starting with [simple URDF model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/d3e8567822e35b306985a14baeea15bd7373c60c/urdf_test/urdf_inertia_test.model?at=urdf_test), I used gzsdf to generate the [corresponding SDF](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/d3e8567822e35b306985a14baeea15bd7373c60c/urdf_test/urdf_inertia_test_generated.sdf?at=urdf_test).  Manually verified that the lumped mass in the generated SDF matches computed value from incoming URDF.
values.title: fix inertia lumping per [drcsim issue 308](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/308/inertia-calculation-for-fixed-joints).

summary.raw:
per [drcsim issue 308](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/308/inertia-calculation-for-fixed-joints)

starting with [simple URDF model](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/d3e8567822e35b306985a14baeea15bd7373c60c/urdf_test/urdf_inertia_test.model?at=urdf_test), I used gzsdf to generate the [corresponding SDF](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/d3e8567822e35b306985a14baeea15bd7373c60c/urdf_test/urdf_inertia_test_generated.sdf?at=urdf_test).  Manually verified that the lumped mass in the generated SDF matches computed value from incoming URDF.
summary.html:
per drcsim issue 308

starting with simple URDF model, I used gzsdf to generate the corresponding SDF. Manually verified that the lumped mass in the generated SDF matches computed value from incoming URDF.

values.title: minor performance improvements.  Change for loops to dot6() where allowed.  Reuse findex[index].

values.description:
This pull-request is very low priority. Keep in mind that nightly builds are not targeted from default, so this should not affect the VRC.

Two new sensors have been added: Sonar, and Force Torque.

The sonar sensor currently uses a cone mesh for detecting range values. The force-torque sensor is a light wrapper around joint feedback.

Both sensors can be visualized in the GUI.

Example worlds: `worlds/sonar_demo.world` and `worlds/force_torque_demo.world`

Resolves Issue #379
values.title: Sonar and Force Torque sensors

values.description:
Fix for issue #701

Change to use a cleaner and more efficient solution. 

The original approach disables and re-enables shadows through ogre SceneManager on every frame which destroys shadow textures and changes internal properties of camera frustums in the scene.
values.title: Disable shadow rendering gpu laser viewport

values.description: This adds a tactile pressure sensor as a plugin for a contact sensor with box-shaped collision elements. The plugin sums the normal forces acting on each contact pad and computes pressure by dividing by the area of the box. The area is computed by multiplying the two largest box dimensions of a contact element. The sensor readings are output on a new message type `tactile.proto`. An example world `pressure_sensor.world` is included.
values.title: Tactile pressure sensor

summary.raw: This adds a tactile pressure sensor as a plugin for a contact sensor with box-shaped collision elements. The plugin sums the normal forces acting on each contact pad and computes pressure by dividing by the area of the box. The area is computed by multiplying the two largest box dimensions of a contact element. The sensor readings are output on a new message type `tactile.proto`. An example world `pressure_sensor.world` is included.
summary.html: This adds a tactile pressure sensor as a plugin for a contact sensor with box-shaped collision elements. The plugin sums the normal forces acting on each contact pad and computes pressure by dividing by the area of the box. The area is computed by multiplying the two largest box dimensions of a contact element. The sensor readings are output on a new message type tactile.proto. An example world pressure_sensor.world is included.

values.description:
This fixes #708, which involves a seg-fault when the Node is unable to access the topic namespaces. It's an edge case, but it's easy to fix.

The namespaces variable is being accessed even if it's empty. This patch fixes that.
values.title: Fix #708: improper memory access in Node::Init

summary.raw:
This fixes #708, which involves a seg-fault when the Node is unable to access the topic namespaces. It's an edge case, but it's easy to fix.

The namespaces variable is being accessed even if it's empty. This patch fixes that.
summary.html:
This fixes #708, which involves a seg-fault when the Node is unable to access the topic namespaces. It's an edge case, but it's easy to fix.

The namespaces variable is being accessed even if it's empty. This patch fixes that.

values.description:
Memory consumption of gzserver should now stay below 2.0Gb. Please try to break it. 

There should also be a decent performance improvement, achieved by avoiding unnecessary new/deletes in `Connection.cc`.

Resolves a few valgrind issues: issue #709, issue #710, issue #711, issue #712

**Jenkins**

http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/39/

http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/drcsim/job/drcsim-drcsim_2.6-gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-sl-vrc/18/

values.description:
Idea is to resolve a blocking call in gzserver transport layer.

Separated out `ConnectionManager's` `publisher_update` packet types into `publisher_subscribe` and `publisher_advertise`. The server processes `publisher_advertise` packets when gzclient connects and so made that non-blocking and also sped it up using tbb.

Fixed a memory leak in Connection.cc.
values.title: Prevent atlas from falling when gzclient connects

summary.raw:
Idea is to resolve a blocking call in gzserver transport layer.

Separated out `ConnectionManager's` `publisher_update` packet types into `publisher_subscribe` and `publisher_advertise`. The server processes `publisher_advertise` packets when gzclient connects and so made that non-blocking and also sped it up using tbb.

Fixed a memory leak in Connection.cc.
summary.html:
Idea is to resolve a blocking call in gzserver transport layer.

Separated out ConnectionManager's publisher_update packet types into publisher_subscribe and publisher_advertise. The server processes publisher_advertise packets when gzclient connects and so made that non-blocking and also sped it up using tbb.

Fixed a memory leak in Connection.cc.

values.description:
This is Ian's branch, but I'm creating the pull request to move discussion away from pull request #573.

This branch has been tested on Jenkins:

Builds with all tests passing:

[drcsim_2.6-gazebo-any gpu-sl-vrc 17](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/drcsim-drcsim_2.6-gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-sl-vrc/17/)

Build with failure documented in [drcsim issue #313](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/313/vrc_task_2_scoringtest-failure-with-nans):

values.description:
This PR adds a minimal package.xml file which allows gazebo to be built in a catkin workspace. This is a similar approach to what the orocos team is doing for convenient ros integration.

catkin_build_isolated can build standard cmake packages into a workspace along with catkin packages. This enables us to do things like create a local underlay for a project which contains the gazebo sources as well as the gazebo-ros integration packages and build them all with one command.
values.title: Adding package.xml to support catkin_build_isolated

summary.raw:
This PR adds a minimal package.xml file which allows gazebo to be built in a catkin workspace. This is a similar approach to what the orocos team is doing for convenient ros integration.

catkin_build_isolated can build standard cmake packages into a workspace along with catkin packages. This enables us to do things like create a local underlay for a project which contains the gazebo sources as well as the gazebo-ros integration packages and build them all with one command.
summary.html:
This PR adds a minimal package.xml file which allows gazebo to be built in a catkin workspace. This is a similar approach to what the orocos team is doing for convenient ros integration.

catkin_build_isolated can build standard cmake packages into a workspace along with catkin packages. This enables us to do things like create a local underlay for a project which contains the gazebo sources as well as the gazebo-ros integration packages and build them all with one command.

values.description:
gzlog, or any other gz* tool, would hang if a gzserver is not present. 

This pull request times out after 30 seconds of trying to connect to master. 

Resolves Issue #716

**Jenkins**

The following build is marked as failing, but all the tests pass. I think there may be a small issue with the Jenkins script.

http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/drcsim/job/drcsim-drcsim_2.6-gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-sl-tesla/16/

values.title: Apply gazebo extensions to all collisions

values.description:
In the spheres.world at the 'liquid' plugin, there is a <nr_spheres> parameter, if it creates a large number of spheres ~80 and then joints between them, the model explodes, and sometimes this error also appears (which I suppose it has to do that the spheres go out of the visual bounds of the rendering scene?):

gazebo: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' faile

If the number of spheres is smaller, the joints are created without problems.

In my original simulation, the spheres started exploding at around the number ~10, maybe because I had more models loaded in the simulation.
values.title: spheres links question, dynamically created joints exploading

summary.raw:
In the spheres.world at the 'liquid' plugin, there is a <nr_spheres> parameter, if it creates a large number of spheres ~80 and then joints between them, the model explodes, and sometimes this error also appears (which I suppose it has to do that the spheres go out of the visual bounds of the rendering scene?):

gazebo: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' faile

If the number of spheres is smaller, the joints are created without problems.

In my original simulation, the spheres started exploding at around the number ~10, maybe because I had more models loaded in the simulation.
summary.html:
In the spheres.world at the 'liquid' plugin, there is a <nr_spheres> parameter, if it creates a large number of spheres ~80 and then joints between them, the model explodes, and sometimes this error also appears (which I suppose it has to do that the spheres go out of the visual bounds of the rendering scene?):

gazebo: /build/buildd/ogre-1.7.4/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' faile

If the number of spheres is smaller, the joints are created without problems.

In my original simulation, the spheres started exploding at around the number ~10, maybe because I had more models loaded in the simulation.

values.description:
This puts a hard limit on the size of the write queue in Connection.cc, and also adds callbacks to each publisher that are triggered when a message is actually delivered.

Put in buffer limits on the sensors.
values.title: Limit the size of the transport buffers

summary.raw:
This puts a hard limit on the size of the write queue in Connection.cc, and also adds callbacks to each publisher that are triggered when a message is actually delivered.

Put in buffer limits on the sensors.
summary.html:
This puts a hard limit on the size of the write queue in Connection.cc, and also adds callbacks to each publisher that are triggered when a message is actually delivered.

Put in buffer limits on the sensors.

values.description:
I'm not sure if this is the best way to make this fix, but I think the default empty.world in Gazebo makes for a sub-optimal viewing experience. The ambiance is too low and the default viewing angle has you looking at your robot/object from the shadow side. I ran into this issue when comparing the colors of the same robot using the RGB values in Rviz and Gazebo, and came up with this small fix.

Before and after changing empty.world:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/15v59inv4iw6rw7/compare.png

Rviz of same robot:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/ihh4yza02qo5b1u/rrbot_rviz.png
values.title: Made visuals look better in empty world

values.description:
The changes are pretty self-explanatory.

I left in some comments and a few definitions for testing purposes.

I think the biggest gain comes from writing out with a precision of 3 decimals. We can do away with the velocity data. I left it because it didn't seem to effect performance too much. It might make more sense to replace velocity with wrench.
values.title: Reduce the amount of data sent to LogRecord

summary.raw:
The changes are pretty self-explanatory.

I left in some comments and a few definitions for testing purposes.

I think the biggest gain comes from writing out with a precision of 3 decimals. We can do away with the velocity data. I left it because it didn't seem to effect performance too much. It might make more sense to replace velocity with wrench.
summary.html:
The changes are pretty self-explanatory.

I left in some comments and a few definitions for testing purposes.

I think the biggest gain comes from writing out with a precision of 3 decimals. We can do away with the velocity data. I left it because it didn't seem to effect performance too much. It might make more sense to replace velocity with wrench.

values.description:
Currently, the following #include statements both work in gazebo :
~~~
#include "gazebo/common/CommonTypes.hh"
#include "common/CommonTypes.hh"
~~~
This pull request changes all includes to be like the first type, and then removes `${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/gazebo` from the includes list, so that the second type will not compile.

This is a big pull request; it was initially part of the sdf_external pull request #416 (issue #648), but I thought it would be easier to review independently. I recommend viewing it by commits.

Commits 36038c6 to 52c4ee0 were created with the following commands from the root of the gazebo source directory, one per commit:
~~~
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/common`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/physics`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' gazebo/physics/bullet`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' gazebo/physics`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' plugins`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' test/regression`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' examples`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/math`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/gui`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "sensors/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "sensors/@include "gazebo/sensors/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "gui/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "gui/@include "gazebo/gui/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "msgs/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "msgs/@include "gazebo/msgs/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' gazebo/gui`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "rendering/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "rendering/@include "gazebo/rendering/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "rendering/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "rendering/@include "gazebo/rendering/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "sdf/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "sdf/@include "gazebo/sdf/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "gazebo\.hh"' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "gazebo\.hh"@include "gazebo/gazebo.hh"@' $i; done
~~~

The subsequent commits were done manually, and I believe the commit messages speak for themselves. I hope these last commits get the most scrutiny.

[Jenkins results](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/42/): it compiles, has a few test failures (not unusual for amazon-vrc), and has one [strange cppcheck error](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/42/cppcheckResult/?).
values.title: Make #include statements relative to PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR

summary.raw:
Currently, the following #include statements both work in gazebo :
~~~
#include "gazebo/common/CommonTypes.hh"
#include "common/CommonTypes.hh"
~~~
This pull request changes all includes to be like the first type, and then removes `${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/gazebo` from the includes list, so that the second type will not compile.

This is a big pull request; it was initially part of the sdf_external pull request #416 (issue #648), but I thought it would be easier to review independently. I recommend viewing it by commits.

for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done

for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/math`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/gui`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "sensors/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "sensors/@include "gazebo/sensors/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "gui/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "gui/@include "gazebo/gui/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "msgs/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "msgs/@include "gazebo/msgs/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' gazebo/gui`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "rendering/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "rendering/@include "gazebo/rendering/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "rendering/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "rendering/@include "gazebo/rendering/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "sdf/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "sdf/@include "gazebo/sdf/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "gazebo\.hh"' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "gazebo\.hh"@include "gazebo/gazebo.hh"@' $i; done
~~~

The subsequent commits were done manually, and I believe the commit messages speak for themselves. I hope these last commits get the most scrutiny.

[Jenkins results](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/42/): it compiles, has a few test failures (not unusual for amazon-vrc), and has one [strange cppcheck error](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-amazon-vrc/42/cppcheckResult/?).
summary.html:
Currently, the following #include statements both work in gazebo :

#include "gazebo/common/CommonTypes.hh"
#include "common/CommonTypes.hh"

This pull request changes all includes to be like the first type, and then removes ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/gazebo from the includes list, so that the second type will not compile.

This is a big pull request; it was initially part of the sdf_external pull request #416 (issue #648), but I thought it would be easier to review independently. I recommend viewing it by commits.

Commits 36038c6 to 52c4ee0 were created with the following commands from the root of the gazebo source directory, one per commit:

for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/common`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo/physics`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' gazebo/physics/bullet`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' gazebo/physics`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' plugins`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' test/regression`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "physics/' examples`; do sed -i -e 's@include "physics/@include "gazebo/physics/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "common/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "common/@include "gazebo/common/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/math`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' gazebo/gui`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "math/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "math/@include "gazebo/math/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "sensors/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "sensors/@include "gazebo/sensors/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "gui/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "gui/@include "gazebo/gui/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "msgs/' gazebo`; do sed -i -e 's@include "msgs/@include "gazebo/msgs/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' gazebo/gui`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "transport/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "transport/@include "gazebo/transport/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "rendering/' gazebo/rendering`; do sed -i -e 's@include "rendering/@include "gazebo/rendering/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "rendering/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "rendering/@include "gazebo/rendering/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "sdf/' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "sdf/@include "gazebo/sdf/@' $i; done
for i in `grep -rlI 'include "gazebo\.hh"' .`; do sed -i -e 's@include "gazebo\.hh"@include "gazebo/gazebo.hh"@' $i; done

The subsequent commits were done manually, and I believe the commit messages speak for themselves. I hope these last commits get the most scrutiny.

Jenkins results: it compiles, has a few test failures (not unusual for amazon-vrc), and has one strange cppcheck error.

values.description: Nate oversaw this event addition. This was needed so that the gazebo_ros_api_plugin could shutdown properly during a while loop if no roscore was ever loaded.
values.title: Added a signint event when server is being shutdown for use with plugins, etc

values.description:
The sim time milliseconds were used in the real time display (see [TimePanel.cc:204](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/de6b97b7d61c87a71f075e988958a0863e50376d/gazebo/gui/TimePanel.cc?at=default#cl-204)). The fix involves reducing code duplication, so it should be easier to maintain.

If I was a better person I would update the TimePanel_TEST.cc to confirm the fix.

values.description:
Fix for drcsim issue #[318](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/318/laser-scan-timestamp-does-not-make-sense), caused by 2 problems: a) timestamps in Scene are not updated as no pose stamped msgs are received, b) new rendering sensor update strategy. 

The fix modified `~/pose/info` publisher to publish on every iteration so Scene gets timestamps, and added a check in Sensor update to avoid duplicate updates.

Also added a rendering_sensor regression test

Update: added `~/pose/local/info` in addition to `~/pose/info` for local publishing at unthrottled rate
values.title: Fix rendering sensor duplicate timestamps

summary.raw:
Fix for drcsim issue #[318](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/318/laser-scan-timestamp-does-not-make-sense), caused by 2 problems: a) timestamps in Scene are not updated as no pose stamped msgs are received, b) new rendering sensor update strategy. 

The fix modified `~/pose/info` publisher to publish on every iteration so Scene gets timestamps, and added a check in Sensor update to avoid duplicate updates.

Also added a rendering_sensor regression test

Update: added `~/pose/local/info` in addition to `~/pose/info` for local publishing at unthrottled rate
summary.html:
Fix for drcsim issue #318, caused by 2 problems: a) timestamps in Scene are not updated as no pose stamped msgs are received, b) new rendering sensor update strategy.

The fix modified ~/pose/info publisher to publish on every iteration so Scene gets timestamps, and added a check in Sensor update to avoid duplicate updates.

Also added a rendering_sensor regression test

Update: added ~/pose/local/info in addition to ~/pose/info for local publishing at unthrottled rate
